body: cc @guybedford who'll have some thoughts on this and who I'll likely need some help from

Thoughts on the question with dynamic import? Should webpack do webpackJsonp stuff for system.register libraries? Or should it do `_context.import()`?

I think this could be the hardest part of the implementation and maybe the most controversial aspect of the feature.
I believe, unless this has chnaged, that Webpack explicitly has as a design goal not to support unknown dynamic imports in the runtime environment, so that this can be omitted in the output.

So maybe sticking to just the entry module being a System.register format, with subsequent code splits being webpack format and use webpackJsonp?

I still find value in the feature like that ^. Usually I care about getting the overall bundle into SystemJS but don't usually have a strong preference about whether it's SystemJS or webpack who implements the code splitting beyond that

> So maybe sticking to just the entry module being a System.register format, with subsequent code splits being webpack format and use webpackJsonp?

Exactly!

Only entry module in System.register format -> `output.libraryTarget: "system"` (pretty easy)

Code Splitting with System.register and module.import -> `target: "system"` (more involved)

@sokra thanks for the feedback here - could you perhaps suggest what the basic architecture of the approach might be for `output.libraryTarget: "system"` for anyone wanting to attempt an implementation here?

Best see `AmdMainTemplatePlugin` (copy this and change it).

The option values are referenced in `LibraryTemplatePlugin`, where the need plugin need to be added.

For support of dependencies, `system` also need to be added in `ExternalModule`

issue.title: Bridge for webpack dependency resolution
issue.body:
In the interest of supplying dependencies and requirement implementations to s.js, so that we can prevent multiple instances of libraries executing in the Shell (one already provided by the bundle and additional fetched by system), we should have a mechanism to support supplying resolved implementations of the dependency urls system is trying to process. This should be done to help improve performance, prevent redundancy, bandwidth usage and sizing optimization.

I added a pull request to system 0.20 (https://github.com/systemjs/systemjs/pull/1831) that allowed me to provide functions in addition to the standard urls for dependency mapping using the config API.
I was asked to re implement that logic as an extension for system 2.0, using the hooks API.
After investigating and making some progress, I see that the network call for the library / asset / artifact has already been made. The capability offers me a chance to work on the already fetched source code before system pareses it.
I believe, this is an unnecessary call and I feel some capability like a `pre-hook` is needed. That way, we can hook into it much before in the lifecycle and based on the url, supply a library that system can consider "resolved"

What are your thoughts on that?
Would you like me to work on adding a pre-hook capability and then the hook extension to bridge dependencies from non jspm bundlers?

issue.title: Adding support for output.libraryTarget "system"

repository.name: webpack
repository.description: A bundler for javascript and friends. Packs many modules into a few bundled assets. Code Splitting allows for loading parts of the application on demand. Through "loaders", modules can be CommonJs, AMD, ES6 modules, CSS, Images, JSON, Coffeescript, LESS, ... and your custom stuff.

issue.body:
Resolves #8833. cc @sokra @guybedford

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?**
A new feature

**Did you add tests for your changes?**
Yes

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?**
No -- completely new feature

**What needs to be documented once your changes are merged?**
We'll need to update the [output.libraryTarget docs](https://webpack.js.org/configuration/output/#outputlibrarytarget) to indicate that `"system"` is now a valid output option.

issue.title: Brainstorm -- synchronously setting public path for webpack bundles.
Exposing System.register _context variable to bundled code.

repository.name: webpack
repository.description: A bundler for javascript and friends. Packs many modules into a few bundled assets. Code Splitting allows for loading parts of the application on demand. Through "loaders", modules can be CommonJs, AMD, ES6 modules, CSS, Images, JSON, Coffeescript, LESS, ... and your custom stuff.

issue.body:
**Motivation**

The motivation for this change is discussed in https://github.com/systemjs/systemjs/issues/1939.

The change allows users to do things like the following:
```js
// Set the public path on the fly, depending on the dynamic URL that SystemJS downloaded
// this bundle from
const dynamicUrl = __system_context__.meta.url
__webpack_public_path__ = dynamicUrl.slice(0, dynamicUrl.lastIndexOf('/') + 1)
```

<!-- In addition to that please answer these questions: -->

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?**

Feature. This allows webpack users to use the [_context argument provided to System.register bundles](https://github.com/systemjs/systemjs/blob/master/docs/system-register.md#format-definition).

**Did you add tests for your changes?**

Yes.

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?**

No

**What needs to be documented once your changes are merged?**

We need to document that `__system_context__` is a variable available to those bundling to `output.libraryTarget: "system"`.

issue.title: SystemJS Load errors while loading the JS Assets
issue.body:
Question
@guybedford, @joeldenning , @kouts  and all,
I have an angular app which uses systemjs. It has multiple assets - e.g. vendor, main, runtime, polyfills & polyfills-es5.
I wanted to download these assets in parallel for performance reasons so I used Promise.All.  

Promise.all([ System.import('runtime'), System.import('polyfills'), System.import('polyfills-es5'), System.import('vendor'), System.import('main') ]) .then(function(modules) { ... })

With above approach, sometimes (intermittently) seeing load errors like below in production,

Error#1:
Message: Loader error occurred:: TypeError: undefined is not an object (evaluating 'e') Stack:https://my.cosmos.com/L/system.1.1.0.min.js
Error#2
loading https://my.cosmos.com/A/d/vendor.js (SystemJS Error#3 https://git.io/JvFET#3) Stack:https://my.cosmos.com/L/system.1.1.0.min.js
Error#3
Loader error occurred:: Error: Error loading https://my.cosmos.com/A/d/vendor..js (SystemJS Error#3 https://git.io/JvFET#3) Stack:Error: Error loading https://my.cosmos.com/A/d/vendor.js (SystemJS Error#3 https://git.io/JvFET#3)
Error#4
Loader error occurred:: SyntaxError: Block-scoped declarations (let, const, function, class) not yet supported outside strict mode Stack:SyntaxError: Block-scoped declarations (let, const, function, class) not yet supported outside strict mode

Now we are using "depcache". But still seeing these errors.

Is there an alternative or recommended solution that I can use? I feel like I'm missing something obvious.

issue.title: Access webpack vendor chunks from System module
issue.body:
<!-- You can check the radios and checkboxes either before or after you create the issue -->
- SystemJS Version: latest
- Which library are you using?
  - [x] system.js
  - [ ] s.js
  - [ ] system-node.cjs
- Which extras are you using?
  - [ ] AMD extra
  - [ ] Named Exports
  - [ ] Named Register
  - [ ] Transform
  - [ ] Use Default
  - [ ] Global
  - [ ] Dynamic Import Maps
- Are you using any [custom hooks](/docs/hooks.md)? No

Hi, I'm aware that this question is related also to webpack,

[my repo](https://github.com/pavlovp/question-webpack-externals) represents simple case - a react app and a library exporting react component.
The app resolves the library in runtime - works great with System!

The problem is that React library gets duplicated. 
I followed the example from [webpack docs](https://v4.webpack.js.org/plugins/split-chunks-plugin/#split-chunks-example-2).
As you can see, in the 'dist' folder, separate chunk for React is created (when compiling app).

This chunk is JSONP webpack chunk.

Can such chunk be consumed by System.js - can we force Webpack to emit those chunks as System.js modules?

issue.title: SystemJS - proof of concept with Create React App ejected Webpack - unable to access module properties
issue.body:
<!-- You can check the radios and checkboxes either before or after you create the issue -->
- SystemJS Version: 
- Which library are you using?
  - [ X] system.js
  - [ ] s.js
  - [ ] system-node.cjs
- Which extras are you using?
  - [ ] AMD extra
  - [ ] Named Exports
  - [ ] Named Register
  - [ ] Transform
  - [ ] Use Default
  - [ ] Global
  - [ ] Dynamic Import Maps
- Are you using any [custom hooks](/docs/hooks.md)?

### Question

Hi, I have a proof of concept where I am trying to use a Create React App ejected Webpack 5 config as the basis for a module that is exported to System JS format. The config has been updated to support System JS format. The consumer of the module is not able to access the properties that the module exposes. I have followed the System JS guidelines for Webpack config and Webpack dev server config. When I try to load the module, System.import() seems to load the module's main entry, but I am not able to access any of the module's properties. Is there something else I would need to do? 

Consumer app index.html:
```html
        <script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/systemjs@6.8.3/dist/system.min.js"></script>
        <script type="systemjs-importmap">
            {
                "imports": {
                    "wp5-ms": "//localhost:3000/static/js/main.chunk.js"
                }
            }
        </script>
```

Consumer app TypeScript:

```javascript
    React.useEffect(() => {
        const loadExample = async () => {
            const wp5Example = await global.System.import('wp5-ms');
            console.log('wp5Example', wp5Example);
        };

        loadExample();
    }, []);
```

Module main entry file:

```javascript
import "systemjs-webpack-interop/auto-public-path";

console.log("hi outside");
const foo = { foo: "bar" };
export default foo;
```

Console output in consumer application (why is foo not available?):

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1335741/116962545-3e84b380-ac74-11eb-85c9-a54176efb456.png)

Here is the high level output of the SystemJS module that is generated with my Webpack config:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1335741/116962651-93282e80-ac74-11eb-9795-50d5df1ba8f2.png)

body:
Is there any further discussion on this?
> Code Splitting with System.register and module.import -> target: "system" (more involved)

Already added a new issue https://github.com/webpack/webpack/issues/15623.

issue.title: Code Splitting with System.register and __system_context__.import

repository.name: webpack
repository.description: A bundler for javascript and friends. Packs many modules into a few bundled assets. Code Splitting allows for loading parts of the application on demand. Through "loaders", modules can be CommonJs, AMD, ES6 modules, CSS, Images, JSON, Coffeescript, LESS, ... and your custom stuff.

issue.body:
<!-- Please don't delete this template or we'll close your issue -->

## Feature request

As I don't see the implementation of this in https://github.com/webpack/webpack/issues/8833, so I decided to create new issue here.

<!-- Issues that contain questions or support requests will be closed. -->
<!-- Before creating an issue please make sure you are using the latest version of webpack. -->
<!-- Check if this feature needs to be implemented in a plugin or loader instead -->
<!-- If yes: file the issue on the plugin/loader repo -->
<!-- Features related to the development server should be filed on this repo instead -->

**What is the expected behavior?**
1. Code Splitting with System.register

Given
```js
// webpack.config.js
module.exports = {
  entry: 'entry.js',
  output: {
    libraryTarget: 'system',
  },
  externals: {
    'lodash': 'lodash'
  }
}
```
```js
// index.js
import('./sub').then((m) => console.log(m));
```
```js
// sub.js
import _ from 'lodash';
export default _.trim('sub');
```
Expect
```js
// src_sub_js.js
System.register(["lodash"], function(__WEBPACK_DYNAMIC_EXPORT__, __system_context__) {
...
```

2. Convert dynamic `import()` into a `__system_context__.import()`

Given
```js
// webpack.config.js
module.exports = {
  entry: 'entry.js',
  output: {
    libraryTarget: 'system',
  },
  externals: {
    'lodash': 'lodash'
  }
}
```
```js
// index.js
import('lodash').then((m) => console.log(m));
```
Expect
```js
// main.js
System.register([], function(__WEBPACK_DYNAMIC_EXPORT__, __system_context__) {
...

/***/ "lodash":
/*!********************!*\
  !*** external "lodash" ***!
  \********************/
/***/ ((module) => {

module.exports = __system_context__.import('lodash');

/***/ }),
...
```

**What is motivation or use case for adding/changing the behavior?**
This is originally mentioned in https://github.com/webpack/webpack/issues/8833. It will improve the performance by lazy loading the required external modules.

**How should this be implemented in your opinion?**

For the first case, I think we should add a new case `system-register` into https://github.com/webpack/webpack/blob/main/lib/WebpackOptionsApply.js#L184. And probably need to copy `ArrayPushCallbackChunkFormatPlugin` and change accordingly.
For another case, I've done a simple plugin to find all the `importCalls`, the code looks like this
```
compiler.hooks.normalModuleFactory.tap(pluginName, (factory) => {
          // 3 cases per https://webpack.js.org/api/normalmodulefactory-hooks/#parser
	['javascript/auto', 'javascript/dynamic', 'javascript/esm'].forEach((type) => {
		factory.hooks.parser.for(type).tap(pluginName, (parser) => {
			parser.hooks.importCall.tap(pluginName, (expression) => {
				// console.log('importCall =', expression.source.value, arguments.length);
				this.importCalls.push(expression.source.value);
			});
		});
	});
});
```
And I use this webpack config
```
externals: [
	function ({ request }, callback) {
		if (isExternal(externals, request)) {
			if (myPlugin.importCalls.includes(request)) {
				// Lazy load external dynamic imports.
				callback(null, `promise __system_context__.import("${request}")`);
			} else {
				// Eager load external static imports.
				callback(null, `system ${request}`);
			}
		} else {
			callback();
		}
	}
],
```
Please confirm if my directions are correct.

**Are you willing to work on this yourself?**
Yes.
